frame.name: Calendric_unit
frame.definition:
<def-root>Words in this frame name the different parts of the calendric cycle, both man-made and natural. The <fen>Unit</fen> (e.g. <m>Tuesday</m>) specifies some time period as part of a specific larger temporal <fen>Whole</fen> (Tuesday <m>of next week</m>), or may be resolved to an exact time span by a <fen>Relative_time</fen> (<m>next</m> Tuesday). <ex>Jo's mother will visit on <fex name="Relative_time">this coming</fex> <fex name="Unit"><t>Tuesday</t></fex>.</ex> <ex></ex> Very frequently, the <fen>Whole</fen> or <fen>Relative_time</fen> are left out (i.e., DNI), and often should be interpreted as a time period overlapping with the communication, but more generally must be understood from context. So, for example, in the first sentence below, we can imagine that the <fen>Whole</fen> refers to a year (e.g., 1983) that was already mentioned or established in context. In the second example below, the most likely interpretation is the nearest April, whether in this year or the next, and this interpretation is best indicated by indicating the <fen>Relative_time</fen> is DNI.
<ex>On <t><fex name="Unit">April</fex></t> 2 , she finally found her mother . <fex name="Whole">DNI</fex>. </ex> <ex>I 'll come back in <fex name="Unit"><t>April</t></fex> .<fex name="Relative_time">DNI</fex></ex> <ex></ex> Most members of this frame can be used with iterative events, either with a plural <fen>Unit</fen> (<m>on Tuesdays</m>), or marked with <m>every</m> (<m>every April</m>). <ex>On <fex name="Whole">Tuesday and Thursday</fex> <t>afternoons</t> , we have tea .</ex> In this use, when the <fen>Whole</fen> is omitted, the <fen>Whole</fen> should be marked INI. <ex>On <t>Tuesdays</t> , we have tea . <fex name="Whole">INI</fex> </ex> <ex></ex> Words of this frame often occur in a non-lexical construction that uses some Calendric_unit expressions to establish when an event occurred. To capture this information, we use the extra-thematic FEs <fen>Landmark_period</fen> and <fen>Trajector_event</fen> (see Temporal_collocation) on the second layer, as in the following: <ex><fex name="Relative_time">Last</fex> <t><fex name="Unit">Tuesday</fex></t> she said I 'd have to come back .</ex> <ex><fex name="Landmark_period">Last <t>Tuesday</t></fex> <fex name="Trajector_event">she said I 'd have to come back</fex> .</ex> We do not use these FEs for cases where the temporal relationship is introduced by an overt word of the Temporal_collocation frame (like <m>on</m>, <m>in</m>, <m>at</m>, <m>before</m>, etc.). Most lexical units of this frame occur in this construction, with or without requiring a <fen>Relative_time</fen>, while some idiosyncratically do not, so information on the use with the extra-thematic FE <fen>Trajector_event</fen> is lexically specific. <ex></ex> There are a number of non-lexical constructions that evoke this frame, including date constructions (<m>the third</m>, <m>May 5</m>), decade constructions (<m>the oughts</m>), year constructions (<m>1975</m>, <m>24 BCE</m>, <m>10 AH</m>, <m>year 19</m>, etc.), and time-of-day constructions. Although not annotated in this frame, examples such as the following show that the FEs <fen>Unit</fen> and <fen>Whole</fen> are quite appropriate: <ex>The <fex name="Unit">4th</fex> <fex name="Whole">of April</fex> dawned clear and cold .</ex> <ex><fex name="Whole">December</fex> <fex name="Unit">11</fex> was when Alix finally left .</ex> <ex>The <fex name="Unit">23rd</fex> will be snowy . <fex name="Whole">DNI</fex> </ex> <ex>Nothing much happened in the <fex name="Unit">90s</fex> , did it ? <fex name="Whole">DNI</fex> </ex> As described above for the lexical targets that evoke this frame, some non-lexical versions of the frame may also occur in a non-lexical Temporal_collocation construction: <ex>No-one has forgotten what happened the <fex name="Unit">5th</fex> <fex name="Whole">of November</fex> !</ex> <ex>No-one has forgotten <fex name="Trajector_event">what happened</fex> <fex name="Landmark_period">the 5th of November</fex> !</ex> <ex></ex>
Words in this frame figure into a variety of temporal schemas, realized as constructions, primarily cases in which the Calendric_unit serves as a Landmark_period in the Temporal_collocation frame. There are families of constructions in which these words occur, including ones in which weekday names combine with day part names using particular prepositions (e.g. <ment>on Wednesday morning</ment>, cf. <ment>on Wednesday</ment>, but <ment>in the morning</ment>) and ones in which calendric terms fill the slots in multi-word expressions such as N-after-N (e.g. <ment>day after day</ment>), N-by-N (e.g. <ment>week by week</ment>), N-to-N (e.g. <ment>month to month</ment>), etc. More can be found on these in Fillmore (2002). Note, also, the connection between this frame and Frequency, specifically that many iterative adjectives and adverbs are based on calendric terms (e.g. <ment>daily</ment>, <ment>weekly</ment>, <ment>monthly</ment>, etc.).
</def-root>

FE.name: Relative_time
FE.definition:
<def-root><fen>Relative_time</fen> is used for the word or words that locate the time with respect to an identifiable reference point.
<ex>Jo's mother will visit <fex name="RelT"> this coming</fex> <t>Tuesday</t>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Name
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Name</fen> is used for the name of a day (month, etc.). Note that only the word (or words) that is the name is (are) tagged, not the target word. <ex><fex name="Name">Labor</fex> <t>Day</t> is just around the corner.</ex> <ex>January is <fex name="Name">Black History</fex> <t>Month</t>.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Whole
FE.definition:
<def-root><fen>Whole</fen> is used for the larger unit of which the target word names a part.
<ex>Jo fled in the early <t>morning</t> <fex name="Whole">of Sunday December 15</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Count
FE.definition:
<def-root>The number of intervals of the specified type.
<ex>These last <fex name="cou">two</fex> <t>weeks</t>, I just keep getting myself into trouble .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Unit
FE.definition: <def-root>The calendric unit that is denoted. LUs in this frame all denote the <fen>Unit</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Salient_event
FE.definition:
<def-root>An event saliently associated with a particular calendric unit.
<ex>Today was my school's <fex name="sal_eve">cut</fex> <t>day</t>.</ex>
<ex>Republicans have indicated they plan to make Kerry's positions an <fex name="sal_eve">election</fex> <t>year</t> issue.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Landmark_period
FE.definition:
<def-root>The time-expression that is used to establish when the <fen>Trajector_event</fen> occurred. This FE, when present, always occurs on the second layer.
<ex>Turn in your expense reports <fex name="Landmark_period">next <t>April</t></fex> .</ex>
This FE is not to be used when the relationship between a time expression and an event is overtly expressed by a target of the Temporal_collocation frame, as in the following, which differs from the preceding sentence only in the use of <m>by</m>:
<ex>Turn in your expense reports by next <t>April</t> .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Trajector_event
FE.definition:
<def-root>An event that is located by the Calendric_unit expression.
<ex>Last <t>November</t> , <fex name="TR">they selected a new president</fex> .</ex>
This FE is not to be used when a target of the Temporal_collocation frame explicitly introduces the temporal relationship between the <fen>Landmark_period</fen> and the <fen>Trajector_event</fen>, as in the following, which differs from the above only in the additional word <m>over</m>:
<ex>Over last <t>November</t> , they selected a new president .</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: day.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a twenty-four-hour period as a unit of time, reckoned from one midnight to the next and corresponding to a rotation of the earth on its axis

lexUnit.name: week.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the period of seven days generally reckoned from and to midnight on Saturday night

lexUnit.name: daybreak.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: dawn

lexUnit.name: weekday.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a day of the week other than Sunday or Saturday

lexUnit.name: weekend.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: Saturday and Sunday

lexUnit.name: weeknight.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a night of the week exclusive of Saturday and Sunday

lexUnit.name: dawn.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the first appearance of light in the sky before sunrise

lexUnit.name: morning.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the period of time between midnight and noon, especially from sunrise to noon

lexUnit.name: noon.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: twelve o'clock in the day; midday

lexUnit.name: Monday.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the day of the week before Tuesday and following Sunday;Patterns like: Calendric_unit.Wednesday.n

lexUnit.name: Tuesday.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the day of the week before Wednesday and following Monday; Patterns like: Calendric_unit.Wednesday.n

lexUnit.name: Wednesday.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the day of the week before Thursday and following Tuesday

lexUnit.name: Thursday.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the day of the week before Friday and following Wednesday; Patterns like: Calendric_unit.Wednesday.n

lexUnit.name: Friday.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the day of the week before Saturday and following Thursday; Patterns like: Calendric_unit.Wednesday.n

lexUnit.name: Saturday.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the day of the week before Sunday and following Friday; Patterns like: Calendric_unit.Wednesday.n

lexUnit.name: today.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: this present day

lexUnit.name: yesterday.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the day before today

lexUnit.name: tomorrow.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the day after today

lexUnit.name: midday.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the middle of the day; noon

lexUnit.name: afternoon.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the time from noon or lunchtime to evening

lexUnit.name: dusk.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the darker stage of twilight

lexUnit.name: evening.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the period of time at the end of the day, between late afternoon and bedtime

lexUnit.name: eve.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the evening or day before a religious festival

lexUnit.name: night.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the time from sunset to sunrise

lexUnit.name: midnight.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: twelve o'clock at night; the middle of the night

lexUnit.name: twilight.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the time of day when the sun is just below the horizon, especially between sunset and dark

lexUnit.name: month.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: each of the twelve named periods into which a year is divided

lexUnit.name: year.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the period of 365 days (or 366 days in leap years) starting from the first of January, used for reckoning time in ordinary affairs

lexUnit.name: calendar year.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the period of time which begins on Janurary 1st and ends on December 31st.

lexUnit.name: fortnight.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a period of two weeks

lexUnit.name: decade.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a period of ten years.

lexUnit.name: January.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the first month of the year. Patterns like: Calendric_unit.April.n

lexUnit.name: February.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the second month of the year. Patterns like: Calendric_unit.April.n

lexUnit.name: March.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the third month of the year. Patterns like: Calendric_unit.April.n

lexUnit.name: April.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the fourth month of the year

lexUnit.name: May.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the fifth month of the year. Patterns like: Calendric_unit.April.n

lexUnit.name: June.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the sixth month of the year. Patterns like: Calendric_unit.April.n

lexUnit.name: July.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the seventh month of the year. Patterns like: Calendric_unit.April.n

lexUnit.name: August.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the eighth month of the year. Patterns like: Calendric_unit.April.n

lexUnit.name: September.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the ninth month of the year. Patterns like: Calendric_unit.April.n

lexUnit.name: October.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the tenth month of the year. Patterns like: Calendric_unit.April.n

lexUnit.name: November.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the eleventh month of the year. Patterns like: Calendric_unit.April.n

lexUnit.name: December.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the twelfth month of the year. Patterns like: Calendric_unit.April.n

lexUnit.name: Sunday.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the day of the week before Monday and following Saturday

lexUnit.name: leap year.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a year, occurring once every four years, which has 366 days including 29 February as an intercalary day

lexUnit.name: morn.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: morning (poetic/literary)

lexUnit.name: winter.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the coldest season of the year, after autumn and before spring: Patterns like: Calendric_unit.autumn.n

lexUnit.name: spring.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the season after winter and before summer, in which vegetation begins to appear; Patterns like: Calendric_unit.autumn.n

lexUnit.name: summer.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the season after spring and before autumn, when the weather is warmest; Patterns like: Calendric_unit.autumn.n

lexUnit.name: hour.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a period of time equal to a twenty-fourth part of a day and night and divided into 60 minutes

lexUnit.name: minute.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a period of time equal to sixty seconds or a sixtieth of an hour

lexUnit.name: second.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a sixtieth of a minute of time, which as the SI unit of time is defined in terms of the natural periodicity of the radiation of a caesium-133 atom

lexUnit.name: autumn.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the season after summer and before winter

lexUnit.name: school year.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a period of time when school is held, which starts after a summer and ends before the next summer.

lexUnit.name: quarter.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a period of three months, used especially in reference to financial transactions

lexUnit.name: era.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a major division of time that is a subdivision of an aeon and is itself subdivided into periods.

lexUnit.name: age.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a distinct period of history.

lexUnit.name: rush hour.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a time at the start and end of the working day when traffic is at its heaviest.

lexUnit.name: tonight.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: this present evening

lexUnit.name: century.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the period of 100 years

lexUnit.name: millennium.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a period of a thousand years, especially when calculated from the traditional date of the birth of Christ.

lexUnit.name: holiday.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a day n which festival, celebration, or religious event is observed

lexUnit.name: one day.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: An unspecified day or occasion is referenced without respect to a specific relative time, hence the incorporation of that FE. This MWE is always indefinite.
